title: Self-Improvement Towards Pareto Optimality: Mitigating Preference Conflicts in Multi-Objective Alignment
author: Moxin Li (National University of Singapore), Yuantao Zhang (National University of Singapore), Wenjie Wang (National University of Singapore), Wentao Shi (University of Science and Technology of China), Zhuo Liu (University of Science and Technology of China), Fuli Feng (University of Science and Technology of China), Tat-Seng Chua (National University of Singapore), ...
relevance_why: The paper's focus on Multi-Objective Alignment (MOA) techniques and preference optimization can be connected to generative audio applications, where multiple objectives such as audio quality and processing speed need to be simultaneously addressed.
background: Multi-Objective Alignment (MOA) optimizes Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate responses that align with multiple human preferences simultaneously, which often conflict.
contribution: This paper introduces a Self-Improvement Direct Preference Optimization framework to construct Pareto-optimal responses, effectively resolving preference conflicts and improving the optimization landscape for LLMs.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods using Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) often struggled with conflicting objectives in alignment data, resulting in poor optimization performance.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enables the generation of Pareto-optimal responses, which significantly mitigates preference conflicts through a three-stage response generation process.

key_innovation: The methodology highlights self-generated Pareto-optimal responses as a practical approach to resolve multi-objective preference conflicts without extensive manual labeling.
real_world_impact: Improving the alignment of LLMs can enhance applications in user interactions, chatbots, and automated content generation, potentially leading to higher user satisfaction and system efficiency.
limitations: The authors did not discuss specific limitations of their framework or the potential bias in response generation dependent on the training data.

new_terms.Pareto-optimal responses: **Pareto-optimal responses** refer to solutions that are non-dominated across multiple criteria, meaning no other solution can improve one objective without degrading another.
